The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Does the concept of a/an Center need to be defined for a definition of a/an Disjoint Cycles to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of Disjoint Cycles involves two cycles being disjoint if they do not share any common elements. This definition focuses solely on the elements of the cycles and their membership in each respective cycle. It does not require any additional properties of the elements other than their distinctness from each other within their respective cycles.

On the other hand, the concept of a Center pertains to group theory, specifically describing a set of elements in a group that commute with all other elements in that group. This concept is related to the structure and properties of groups, particularly the interactions between elements within the group.

Given these definitions, the concept of a Center is not necessary to understand or define Disjoint Cycles. Disjoint Cycles can be fully understood and defined without reference to group theory or the commuting properties of elements, which are central to the definition of a Center. Therefore, the concept of a Center is not needed for the definition of Disjoint Cycles to make sense.
